"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{16(2)}+\sqrt{9(2)}-\sqrt{25(2)}=4\sqrt{2}+3\sqrt{2}-5\sqrt{2}="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#EC7300}\large\boxed{2\sqrt{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\large\color{#20A900}answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Take the arithmetic progression "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101k, 102k, \ldots, 199k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which has 99 terms. We wish to find a "},{"type":"text","text":"k","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102k, 102k, \ldots, 198k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are powers of positive integers, while 101k and 199k aren't. To be specific, we let "},{"type":"text","text":"S","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" denote the set of primes < 198 and excluding 101, then pick k of the form: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k =\prod_{p \in S} p^{m_p} = 2^{m_2} \times 3^{m_3} \times 5^{m_5} \times\ldots "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"for suitable non-negative integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_2, m_3, m_5, m_7, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Pick any distinct primes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_{102}, q_{103}, \ldots, q_{198}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; for every prime "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p\in S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solve the following congruences:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} m_p + \nu(102, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{102}}, \\
m_p + \nu(103, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{103}},\\
&\vdots \\
m_p + \nu(198, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{198}}. \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\nu(n, p)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the largest "},{"type":"text","text":"j","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" such that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p^j | n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Note that since all prime factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102, \ldots, 198"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lie in S, we have: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 102 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(102, p)}, \ 103 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(103, p)}, \ \ldots, \ 198 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(198, p)}. "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By Chinese Remainder Theorem, there's a solution for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the above congruences. Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k =\prod_{p \in S} p^{m_p}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we see that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 102k = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(102, p)} p^{m_p} = \prod_{p\in S} p^{m_p + \nu(102, p)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_{102}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-th power, and likewise for each of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i = 103, \ldots, 198"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the multiple "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ik"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-th power. Thus, we have a sequence which satisfies (1)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This sequence clearly satisfies (2) as well since 101 and 199 are prime and k is not a multiple of 101 or 199."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            He chose the sequence because it works. See the above discussion for what are the crucial aspects of the sequence that works."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here is a simpler way of understanding the proof, which uses very similar idea. Starting with the sequence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101, 102, \ldots , 199 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (where once again the important criterion is that both 101 and 199 are prime), we want to inductively make each term (from the second) a power."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Base step: Starting with the second, we multiply the sequence by 102, which makes the second term "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is a power."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Induction step: Let the terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_2, a_3, \ldots a_k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be powers. Let the LCM of the exponents be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then, multiplying the entire sequence by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_{k+1}^{M+1} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" makes all the terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_2, \ldots a_{k+1} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a power term."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, it is possible to make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_2, a_3, \ldots a_{98} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" all powers. Now, we check that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (respectively  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{99}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") is not a power. This is because it is a multiple of 101 (resp 199), but not "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (resp "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ).
